titleStmt.title: Variations in Symptom Prevalence and Clinical Correlates in Younger Versus Older Youth with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

availability.p: Ó Springer Science+Business Media New York 2014

Departments of Pediatrics, Psychology , Psychiatry and Behavioral Neurosciences , University of South Florida , Tampa , FL , USA

analytic.title: Variations in Symptom Prevalence and Clinical Correlates in Younger Versus Older Youth with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents
application.label: a91ee48

startPage=-1, endPage=-1, consolidateCitations=2, consolidateHeader=2, consolidateFunders=1, includeRawAffiliations=true, includeRawCitations=true, includeRawCopyrights=true, generateTeiIds=true, generateTeiCoordinates=[all], sentenceSegmentation=true, flavor=null

p.s: Few studies have examined the phenomenology of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in younger children.
A sample of 292 treatment seeking youth with a primary diagnosis of OCD was divided into the young child (3-9 years old) and older child (10-18 years old) groups.
Overall OCD severity did not differ between groups.
However, older youth demonstrated stronger intensity of obsessive and compulsive symptoms, while younger children were rated as having less resistance and control of compulsions.

Older youth exhibited increased occurrence of comorbid depression, and an increased occurrence of sexual, magical thinking, and somatic obsessions, as well as, checking, counting and magical thinking compulsions.

Conversely, the group of younger children exhibited significantly poorer insight, increased incidence of hoarding compulsions, higher rates of comorbid attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, disruptive behavior, and parent-rated anxiety, and more frequently exhibited hoarding compulsions.
These differences suggest domains to consider when screening for OCD among younger/older pediatric cohorts.

Characterized by excessive, anxiety-inducing intrusive thoughts (i.e., obsessions) and ritualistic, distress reducing behaviors (i.e., compulsions) [1], obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a psychiatric disorder with a lifetime prevalence of over 1-2 % in the general population [2].
In children, clinical levels of obsessions and compulsions contribute to a significant functional impairment in school, with friends, and with family, as well as diminished quality of life [3][4][5].
Initially, the clinical picture of pediatric OCD, like many other psychiatric disorders that occur across the lifespan (e.g., depression), was developed as a downward extension of adult presentation.

Although the presentation of OCD in childhood is generally similar to adulthood, there are a number of unique developmental and familial characteristics of pediatric OCD that were not evident until study of OCD in youth became more commonplace.

For example, comparison of youth versus adults with OCD have identified a number of differences including gender prevalence (i.e., pediatric OCD is more common among males as compared to among females in adults) [6,7], comorbid disorders [e.g., attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is more common among youth] [6,8,9], level of insight (i.e.
typically worse among youth than adults) [6,8] as well as symptom prevalence and presentation (e.g., youth more frequently endorse aggressive obsessions than adults) [10][11][12].
While most studies have examined phenomenological differences between adult and pediatric OCD, developmental differences within youth are also considerable.
It follows that, similar to differences in adults versus youth, presentation of OCD may differ between younger and older youth.

Investigation of other psychiatric illnesses have suggested that a child's age is an important factor in determining the clinical presentation, with symptomatic differences across ages of youths noted within ADHD (e.g., hyperactivity more common among younger children) [13] and depression (e.g., greater somatic complaints and agitation among younger children compared to higher rates of anhedonia, hopelessness, and suicide among older youth) [14,15].
To date, only four studies [11,[16][17][18] (see Table 1) have investigated differences in OCD phenomenology across youth of different ages, resulting in mixed results.
In general, it appears that youth present with comparable levels of overall severity [11,[16][17][18].
Regarding symptom profile, a number of significant differences have been observed, though none have been consistently identified.

For obsessions, some studies have found that older youth present with higher levels of contamination obsessions [16] and religious and sexual obsessions [11] as compared to younger children; however, other studies have found no differences among frequency of obsessions [17,18].

Although studies have found washing and checking rituals [16], as well as ordering and repeating compulsions [18] to occur more frequently in older youth than younger youth, others did not replicate these results [11,17].

Geller et al. [11] found young children were more likely to present with poor insight than older youth, a finding also noted in a study of insight [19], though this result was not replicated by Farrell et al. [16].
Similarly, there is cross-study variation in reports of gender and comorbidity.
For example, most studies suggest that OCD has a male preponderance in youth [11,17,18].
However, one study found a shift to female preponderance in adolescence [16].

Comorbidity patterns appear consistent with patterns of onset for psychopathology, with younger children appearing more likely to present with comorbid separation anxiety disorder [11], specific phobia [16], tics [11,18], and oppositional defiant disorder [16], while older youth more likely to be diagnosed with comorbid major depressive disorder [11].
Differences in findings across studies may be due to a number of study specific methodological variations complicating cross-study comparisons.
For example, three studies featured relatively small samples of children and adolescents (see Table 1) and therefore may have been underpowered for a number of comparisons.

The age at which groups were divided ranged between 10 and 13 across studies and, while most studies based groups upon the children's age at the time of assessment, Nakatani et al. [18] separated groups based upon retrospective report of age-of-OCD-onset.
These methodological differences (and in some cases small sample sizes; e.g., Mancebo et al. [17]) across studies may partially explain variation in outcomes.

Thus, further study of this population within a large sample, appropriately powered to detect small effects, is warranted to better understand the potential differences in OCD presentation and clinical characteristics between these two groups.
Consequently we investigated phenomenological differences between older versus younger children with OCD (N = 292).

This study examines possible differences in overall severity, endorsement of symptom types, frequency of comorbid conditions, medication usage and differences in insight and control in younger (9 years or younger) and older (10 years and above) youth.
We selected these age ranges given that research suggests that for OCD, differences in clinical profile begin to emerge at 10 years old [18,20].
However, age was also explored as a continuous predictor of obsessive-compulsive severity and symptom endorsement.
We predicted that younger age would be associated with a higher male predominance, increased instance of ODD, and anxiety, as well as lower clinician rated insight.
We also predicted that older age would be associated with a higher predominance of major depressive disorder.
Data for the present study were collected from 292 CBTseeking youth (50.3 % male) presenting to a specialty clinic for youth with OCD and related disorders.

The sample of 292 was formed using data combined from two types of studies, namely: (a) 110 youth from treatment outcome studies of CBT, using data from the initial baseline assessment (treatment outcome data presented in the following studies: [21,22]); and (b) 182 youth from single time point evaluations (data for these participants is presented in the following studies: [23,24] ).
The sample was divided into the younger youth (n = 99; M = 7.46; SD = 1.42; range 3-9) and older youth (n = 193; M = 12.83 SD = 2.14; range 10-18) groups.
All participants in the present study had a primary diagnosis of OCD determined by senior clinician diagnosis and confirmed by diagnostic interview; medication was not exclusionary.
Comorbid disorders were common, with 74.8 % (n = 223) meeting criteria for at least one, and 33.6 % (n = 100) meeting criteria for two or more.
Full participant demographics are presented in Table 2.
Children's Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (CYBOCS) [25] Administered by the clinician, the CYBOCS is a semistructured measure of presence and severity of OCD symptoms in youth.
The CYBOCS is composed of a detailed symptom checklist that assesses for specific obsessions and compulsions, as well as ten items that assess various aspects of OCD severity using a 5-point scale.
An obsessions (items 1-5), compulsions (items 6-10) and total severity (items 1-10) score is yielded.

In addition, obsessions and compulsions severity scores were subdivided to examine intensity of obsessions (items 1-3) and compulsions (items 6-8), as well as the amount of resistance and control over obsessions (items 4-5) and compulsions (items 9-10) [26].

For purposes of data analysis on the CYBOCS symptom checklist, participants were considered to have a specific symptom area if at least one item on the CYBOCS checklist within that area was identified.
Insight was also assessed using the CYBOCS (item 11).
The CYBOCS has demonstrated excellent reliability and validity [27][28][29] and is considered the goldstandard in pediatric OCD assessment [30].
In the present study, internal consistency for the CYBOCS was good (a = 0.84).
Comprised of a single, 7-point item, the CGI-S is used as a clinician rated measure of global OCD burden.
The psychometric properties of the CGI-S are well established [32,33].

Family Accommodation items [34] Thirteen clinician-rated items, administered to parents, were used to assess the extent to which family members are involved in accommodation of, as well as the extent to which they are distressed/impaired by, a child's obsessivecompulsive symptoms.
Psychometrics of the family accommodation items has been established including interrater reliability, internal consistency, convergent and discriminant validity [34][35][36][37].
Internal consistency of the family accommodation items was good in the present sample (a = 0.84).

div.head: Multidimensional Anxiety Scale for Children-Parent Version [38]

p.s: Consisting of 39, 4-point Likert-type, parent-report items, the MASC-P is a modified version of the MASC used to assess general, social and separation anxiety in youth as measured by parents.
Reliability and validity of the MASC-P scores have been established [39] and excellent internal consistency was observed within the present sample (a = .91).
Raw scores were utilized in this study given the lack of normative data for the MASC-P.

Children's Sheehan Disability Scale (CSDS) [40] The CSDS is a brief, 3-item self-report measure of symptom-related impairment in work, social life and family life that has demonstrated high convergent validity, construct validity and treatment sensitivity [40] and good internal consistency in the present sample (a = 0.86).

Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule for Children & Parents (ADIS) [41] The ADIS is a clinician-administered structured diagnostic interview that assess the presence and severity of anxiety disorders, as well as other common childhood conditions.
Psychometric properties for the ADIS, including inter-rater reliability, test-retest reliability, and concurrent validity, are excellent [42,43].
The ADIS was used to confirm primary OCD diagnoses and the presence of comorbidity.
Institutional review board approval for this research was granted.
As part of standard clinic procedure, all youth completed an initial unstructured diagnostic assessment with an experienced psychologist or psychiatrist prior to research involvement.
Following this, youth were directed towards any ongoing studies, for which they may meet eligibility criteria.
Written informed consent and assent was obtained from parent/child participants in each of the studies from which this sample was drawn.
For 18 year old participants, direct consent was provided, while parents provided consent to complete their portion of the assessment.

Diagnostic decisions for a primary diagnosis of OCD, as well as of comorbid disorders, were made by a consensus panel of two licensed clinical psychologists using best estimate procedures [23,44], which involved integrating impressions from structured clinical interviews by experienced masters/doctoral level clinician (ADIS, CYBOCS) and unstructured clinical intake evaluations by an experienced psychologist or psychiatrist [23].

While demographic information, as well as CYBOCS and CGI-S scores were collected across all studies, other clinical measures, namely the family accommodation items, MASC-P and CSDS were not consistently assessed across all studies as each study had a unique clinical focus.
The size of partial samples obtained for these measures are reported along side their analyses.
Independent samples t-tests were used to examine between-group differences on continuous dependent variables (i.e.
obsessive-compulsive severity, clinical correlates), while Chi square tests were employed to examine between-group differences on categorical dependent variables (i.e.
clinical characteristics, endorsement of symptom dimensions).

Examination of age as a continuous predictor of symptom severity was completed using linear regression, while examination of age as a continuous predictor of symptom endorsement was completed using logistic regression.
Power analyses revealed the present sample had power of 0.8 (a = 0.05) to detect effects as small as d = 0.16 for Chi square and d = 0.35 for independent samples t-tests.
In the present sample a number of differences were observed between younger and older children with OCD (see Table 2).
In particular, older youth were significantly more likely to present with a comorbid depressive disorder (5.1 vs.
while younger children were more likely to present with comorbid ADHD (29.3 vs. 16.1 %; X 2 (1) = 7.02, p \ .01)
and disruptive behavior (20.2 vs.

Consistent with diagnostic differences, older youth were significantly more likely to be prescribed antidepressants (20.5 vs. 47.8 %; X 2 (1) = 17.77, p \ .01),
while younger youth were significantly more likely to be prescribed stimulants (22.7 vs. 12.3 %; X 2 (1) = 4.57, p \ .01).
Older youth were also more likely to be prescribed anticonvulsants (6.9 vs. 0 %; X 2 (1) = 7.14, p \ .01).
No significant differences were observed between groups in regards to gender or ethnicity.
In terms of obsessive-compulsive symptoms as measured by the CYBOCS, groups did not significantly differ in total severity [t(290) = -1.58,
however, older youth were rated as having increased obsessive severity [t(290) = -2.
When item-level responses were examined, older youth were rated as having increased intensity of both obsessive [t(290) = -3.24,
and compulsive symptoms [t(290) = -2.21,
while younger youth were rated as having significantly poorer resistance and control against compulsions [t(290) = 2.01, p \ .05]
and insight [t(290) = -3.02,
see Table 3].
A single clinician rating of obsessive-compulsive severity (CGI-S) also did not significantly differ between groups [t(290) = -1.51,
Generally, symptom occurrence was similar across groups, with the majority of differences indicating higher frequency among older youth (see Table 4).
In particular, the older group presented with significantly more sexual, magical thinking, and somatic obsessions, as well as significantly more checking, counting and magical thinking compulsions.
The only symptom dimension identified significantly more frequently in younger children was hoarding compulsions (42.4 vs. 29.0

The range of prevalence of specific symptom domains reported in past studies, along with those found for the present study, is included in Table 4. Compared with past studies, the present study reported generally similar symptom frequencies, with most falling within the range of prevalence reported in past studies.
However, some specific symptom dimensions did appear to vary from the prevalence of past studies.

Family accommodation and level of impairment (CSDS) did not differ significantly between groups; however, parent-reported anxiety was rated significantly higher in the younger group than the older [t(126) = 2.24, p \ .05;
see
Table 5].
This appeared to be driven primarily by significantly higher report of social [t(137) = 2.50, p \ .05]
and separation fears [t(132) = 4.49, p \ .01]
by parents of younger children.
Age as a Continuous Variable In order to further examine the impact of age, regression analyses were conducted.
Consistent with the dichotomized results, age was found to be related to increased severity of obsessions [b = -0.19,
In the present study, we examined differences in symptom severity and presentation, as well as clinical correlates between younger and older youth with OCD.
Methodological variability in extant studies has limited the clarity of conclusions [11,[16][17][18].
Using a large, sufficiently-powered sample of youth, our study attempted to replicate prior results and better solidify an understanding of how these two groups differ.
In general, the present study provides further support for a distinction between the presentation of OCD in younger versus older youth.
Consistent with previous observations, youth did not differ in the overall severity of their obsessive compulsive symptoms.
Examination of symptoms in more detail did reveal that older youth experience more intense symptoms, but were better able to control or resist compulsive behaviors.
In addition, younger children were observed to have significantly less insight into symptoms.

Regarding obsessions, the present study confirmed increased frequency of sexual obsessions in older youth identified by Geller et al. [11], but did not replicate findings of differences in religious [11], contamination [16], or aggressive obsessions [17].
In addition, the present sample did note higher levels of somatic and magical thinking obsessions in older youth.
For compulsions, the present study similarly identified a higher presence of checking compulsions in older youth to Farrell et al. [16]; however, no other consistent differences (i.e.
washing, ordering, and repeating compulsions) were observed.

Again, the present study identified three new differences, noting older youth endorsed more counting and magical thinking compulsions while younger youth were more likely to endorse hoarding compulsions.

Depressive disorders were significantly more common among older youth (also identified by Geller et al. [11]), while oppositional behavior was more common among younger youth (also observed by Farrell et al. [16]).

While no differences were identified in the presence of any anxiety disorder, results of the MASC-P suggest that younger youth were more likely to present with significant separation anxiety and social fears than older youth.
Not previously identified, ADHD was also significantly more common amongst younger youth in the present sample.
Consistent with overall obsessive compulsive severity, family accommodation and overall level of impairment were not found to be significantly different between age groups.
Many of the differences observed between youth can likely be explained by the natural course of development.
For example, patterns of comorbidity observed are also consistent with typical ages of onset for those disorders in non-OCD samples.

Specifically, separation anxiety and ADHD onset in early childhood and tend to decrease in prevalence over developmental course [45], while depressive disorders more commonly emerge in early adolescence [45,46].
In general, collecting behaviors are common and developmentally appropriate in young children [47][48][49].
While age-appropriate collecting is conceptually different from hoarding [50], this may explain a higher frequency of reported hoarding compulsions in younger youth.
This seems particularly likely, given the lack of difference in reported hoarding-related obsessions between groups.
In addition, differences observed in the present study may be partially explained by developmental changes associated with puberty.
For example, evidence indicates that increases in gonadal and adrenal hormones in males, as well as early onset of puberty in females, are associated with increased anxiety in adolescence [51].
Similarly, differences in level of insight can likely be explained by increased cognitive development in older youth rather than by differences in the nature of OCD between groups.
This difference may also then contribute to those observed in regards to severity of obsessions, as well as lack of resistance and control of compulsions in younger youth.
Older youth who have better insight, may be more cognizant of obsessional thoughts and therefore more able/likely to report them and/or feel more disturbed by them.

It is also possible, considering the present study did not control for age of onset, that increased severity in older youth may be related to a longer duration of illness, which has previously been identified as a predictor of increased severity [20].

While many previous observations regarding differences amongst youth were replicated, the findings of the present study, particularly in regards to symptom profile, were not entirely consistent with previous research in the area.
As discussed earlier, methodological variations, such as the nature of the age cut off, may have resulted in a different composition of groups and therefore identified varying differences.
A number of sample specific confounds may also have contributed to difference, such as varying locations/ cultures, assessors (i.e.
different interpretation of symptoms/ severity), and recruitment.
Finally, considering the number of comparisons made within the present study and past studies, it is possible that some observed significant differences were due to chance.
These explanations appear particularly likely given that the reported prevalence of specific symptom domains across studies has been highly variable.

This suggests the need for further research in the area, particularly the use of meta-analytic techniques which could synthesize prevalence rates across studies, in order to determine which differences are best explained by age rather than extraneous variables or chance.
A number of limitations of the present study should be noted.
First, the present study did not collect age of OCD onset, prior treatment history, or information on puberty or cognitive development.
As a result, some of the differences observed between groups may be better explained by these specific factors rather than general age differences.
Second, due to the varying nature and purpose of the studies included in the data, clinical data was not perfectly consistent across studies.
As a result, group composition varied across the additional analyses in the present study.
In addition, as a result, inter-rater reliability could not be calculated for diagnostic assessments.
Third, the present study utilized a convenience sample of individuals seeking behavioral treatment for OCD.
As a result, participants may have had unique characteristics (e.g., less amenable to medication, refractory to previous treatment) that may not be representative of all youth with OCD.
Fourth, while the present study is better powered than previous examinations, age comparisons were based on a cross-sectional sample of youth rather than on a longitudinal comparison.
As a result, variability due to factors other than differences in age, may be present.
Further study is needed to further clarify differences between youth.
While evidence is beginning to establish the presence of differences, the lack of consistency between current studies indicates further research is needed to replicate these differences.
Simultaneously, additional variables should be investigated as potential moderators of age differences.
While Nakatani et al. [18] did not find a relationship between treatment outcome and age of onset, no studies using a time of treatment age cut off have examined this.
To provide a better continuous picture of age differences in youth, further longitudinal study of OCD in youth should be considered.
This may be particularly helpful in clarifying which factors are related to age of onset, duration of symptoms, age regardless of onset, and other potential variables.
The present study provides further evidence for differences in the clinical presentation of youth with OCD.

While results indicated that groups did not differ in regards to overall OCD severity, older youth were rated as having increased intensity of both obsessive and compulsive symptoms, as well as more resistance and control over their compulsions.
In addition, some significant differences in OCD presentation were observed.

In particular, older youth endorsed more sexual, magical thinking, and somatic obsessions, as well as, checking, counting and magical thinking compulsions, while younger children endorsed more hoarding compulsions.

Occurrence of comorbid disorders also differed between groups, with depression more common among older children and ADHD, disruptive behavior, as well as parent-rated anxiety more common among younger children.
No differences were found between groups in regards to the extent of family accommodation or the level of impairment.
In sum, the results suggest that youth with OCD may present with different clinical profiles depending on their age at the time of evaluation.

or total severity [b = 0.09, t(290) = 1.13, p = .26].
Similarly, logistic regression revealed that age was related to an increased likelihood of sexual obsessions (b = .13,
